LeadPara.Para: Top Middle East stories on Monday:

TailParas.Para: BAGHDAD: Sunni Arab, Kurdish and secularist leaders emphatically rejected Iraqi Prime Minister Ibrahim Jaafari staying on in his post, possibly sealing the embattled Shiite premier's political fate.
BAGHDAD: An Iraqi employee of Agence France-Presse, accountant Salah Jali al-Gharrawi, was kidnapped on April 4 in central Baghdad and the agency has no news of his fate.

BERLIN: German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier hailed a video of two German hostages held in Iraq as confirmation that they are still alive and said the government was confident it would secure their release.
RAMALLAH, West Bank: Palestinian leader Mahmud Abbas urged Israel to abandon its efforts to isolate his Hamas-led government as financial pressure on the Islamist regime intensified.
LUXEMBOURG: The European Union vowed to stand by the beleaguered Palestinian people despite suspending aid to their Hamas-run governnment, denying the funding cutoff amounts to "blackmail."

GAZA CITY: The Hamas-led Palestinian government still faces a 120 million dollar monthly budget shortfall, despite having received 35 million dollars from Algeria, finance minister Omar Abdulrazeq said.

TEHRAN: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed he would not back down "one iota" over Iran's nuclear programme, again rejecting a UN Security Council demand for Tehran to freeze sensitive enrichment work.

BEIRUT: Lebanon denied a report that nine had been arrested in a plot to kill Hezbollah chief Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, but confirmed the men had been detained for planning an attack "against the state".
